'''''The Immortals''''' is a sequence of novels written by [[Alyson Noël]], focusing on psychics and immortals. The first two books, ''[[Evermore (novel)|Evermore]]'' and ''[[Blue Moon (Noel novel)|Blue Moon]]'', are [[New York Times Bestseller|''New York Times'' Bestsellers]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/16/books/bestseller/bestchildren.html?_r=1 | work=The New York Times | first=Jennifer | last=Schuessler | title=Hardcover}}</ref>
==Plot==
Since a horrible accident claimed the lives of her family, sixteen-year-old Ever can see auras, hear people’s thoughts, and know a person’s life story by touch. Going out of her way to shield herself from human contact to suppress her abilities has branded her as a freak at her new high school—but everything changes when she meets Damen Auguste.
Damen is gorgeous, exotic and wealthy, and he holds many secrets. Ever doesn’t know who he really is—or what he is. Damen is equal parts light and dark, and he belongs to an enchanted new world where no one ever dies.
== Books in the series== * ''[[Evermore (novel)|Evermore]]'' (February 3, 2009)<ref>{{cite web|last=Noël|first=Alyson|title=Evermore|url=http://www.alysonnoel.com/immortals/evermore.php|work=The Immortals series|publisher=St. Martin's Griffin|accessdate=6 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120501123758/http://www.alysonnoel.com/immortals/evermore.php|archivedate=1 May 2012|df=}}</ref> * ''[[Blue Moon (Noel novel)|Blue Moon]]'' (July 7, 2009)<ref>{{cite web|last=Noël|first=Alyson|title=Blue Moon|url=http://www.alysonnoel.com/immortals/blue-moon.php|work=The Immortals series|publisher=St. Martin's Griffin|accessdate=6 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120429193535/http://www.alysonnoel.com/immortals/blue-moon.php|archivedate=29 April 2012|df=}}</ref> * ''[[Shadowland (Alyson Noel novel)|Shadowland]]'' (November 17, 2009)<ref>{{cite web|last=Noël|first=Alyson|title=Shadowland|url=http://www.alysonnoel.com/immortals/shadowland.php|work=The Immortals series|publisher=St. Martin's Griffin|accessdate=6 May 2012}}</ref> * ''[[Dark Flame (Noel novel)|Dark flame]]'' (June 22, 2010)<ref>{{cite web|last=Noël|first=Alyson|title=Dark Flame|url=http://www.alysonnoel.com/immortals/dark-flame.php|work=The Immortals series|publisher=St. Martin's Griffin|accessdate=6 May 2012}}</ref> * ''[[Night Star (novel)|Night Star]]'' (November 16, 2010)<ref>{{cite web|last=Noël|first=Alyson|title=Night Star|url=http://www.alysonnoel.com/immortals/night-star.php|work=The Immortals series|publisher=St. Martin's Griffin|accessdate=6 May 2012}}</ref> * ''[[Everlasting (Novel)|Everlasting]]'' (June 7, 2011)<ref>{{cite web|last=Noël|first=Alyson|title=Everlasting|url=http://www.alysonnoel.com/immortals/everlasting.php|work=The Immortals series|publisher=St. Martin's Griffin|accessdate=6 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120501132652/http://www.alysonnoel.com/immortals/everlasting.php|archivedate=1 May 2012|df=}}</ref>
Alyson Noel also wrote a spin-off series called the ''[[Riley Bloom Series]]'', featuring Ever's sister, Riley.
On March 28, 2011, author Alyson Noel announced that the rights to all 10 books in both ''The Immortals'' and ''[[Riley Bloom Series]]'' have been optioned by Summit Entertainment.<ref>http://alysonnoel.blogspot.com/2011/03/very-exciting-news.html</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.immortalsseries.com The Immortals: official site] *[http://www.alysonnoel.com/IMMORTALS/index_immortals.php Alyson Noël's web page devoted to "The Immortals"] *[http://www.alysonnoel.com Alyson Noël's website]

{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2014}} {{good article}} {{Infobox ice hockey player | image = Todd Bertuzzi 2005.jpg | image_size = 230px | caption = Bertuzzi with Team Canada in 2005 | played_for = [[New York Islanders]]
[[Vancouver Canucks]]
[[Florida Panthers]]
[[Detroit Red Wings]]
[[Anaheim Ducks]]
[[Calgary Flames]] | league = NHL | position = [[Right Wing (ice hockey)|Right Wing]] | shoots = Left | height_ft = 6 | height_in = 3 | weight_lb = 246 | ntl_team = CAN | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1975|2|2}} | birth_place = [[Greater Sudbury|Sudbury]], [[Ontario]], Canada | draft = 23rd overall | draft_year = 1993 | draft_team = [[New York Islanders]] | career_start = 1995 | career_end = 2014 }} '''Todd Bertuzzi''' (born February 2, 1975) is a Canadian retired professional [[ice hockey]] [[winger (ice hockey)|winger]] of the [[National Hockey League]] (NHL). Known as a [[power forward (ice hockey)|power forward]], he has played in the NHL for the [[New York Islanders]], [[Vancouver Canucks]], [[Florida Panthers]], [[Anaheim Ducks]], [[Calgary Flames]] and [[Detroit Red Wings]]. Selected 23rd overall by the New York Islanders in the [[1993 NHL Entry Draft]], he played at the [[junior ice hockey|junior]] level with the [[Guelph Storm]] of the [[Ontario Hockey League]] (OHL) for four seasons. In [[1995–96 NHL season|1995–96]], he played his rookie season with the Islanders. After two-and-a-half seasons with the Islanders, he was traded to the Vancouver Canucks. Bertuzzi enjoyed the most successful seasons of his career with the Canucks—his longest tenured team in the NHL—including [[NHL All-Star Team|NHL First Team All-Star]] honours in [[2002–03 NHL season|2003]]. After seven-and-a-half seasons with Vancouver, Bertuzzi was dealt to the Florida Panthers, with whom he briefly played for until being traded again to the Red Wings. He then played single seasons with the Anaheim Ducks and the Calgary Flames before returning to Detroit in [[2009–10 NHL season|2009]] and finishing his career there. Internationally, Bertuzzi has competed for [[Canada men's national ice hockey team|Team Canada]] at the [[Ice hockey at the 2006 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|2006 Winter Olympics]] in [[Turin]], as well as the [[1998 Men's World Ice Hockey Championships|1998]] and [[2000 Men's World Ice Hockey Championships|2000 World Championships]]. ==Playing career== ===Guelph Storm (1991–95)=== After playing for two [[minor ice hockey|minor hockey]] teams based out of [[Sudbury, Ontario]] in 1990–91, Bertuzzi was selected in the first round (fifth overall) by the [[Guelph Storm]] in the 1991 [[Ontario Hockey League]] (OHL) Priority Selection. His future coach with the [[Vancouver Canucks]], [[Marc Crawford]], passed on Bertuzzi during the draft while he was general manager of the [[Cornwall Royals]]; he has recalled not selecting him due to "maturity issues" and that he was "a big kid who hadn't grown into his body yet." Bertuzzi started his OHL career for Guelph in [[1991–92 OHL season|1991–92]], recording 21 points over 42 games as a rookie. He missed the last 15 games of the regular season due to suspension as a result of kicking opposing defenceman Brad Barton during a contest between the Storm and [[Kitchener Rangers]].{{cite news |last=Simmons |first=Steve |title=Big Bert's a problem |work=Calgary Sun |date=March 11, 2004 |page=55}}{{Cite news|title=Irrational moment blamed|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/648376651.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Mar+11%2C+2004&author=TOM+CONAWAY&pub=Waterloo+Region+Record&desc=Irrational+moment+blamed&pqatl=google|accessdate=April 12, 2011|date=March 11, 2004|work=[[The Toronto Star]]|first=Tom|last=Conaway}} After improving to 58 points over 60 games in [[1992–93 OHL season|1992–93]], he was selected 23rd overall by the [[New York Islanders]] in the [[1993 NHL Entry Draft]]. The [[NHL Central Scouting Bureau]] described Bertuzzi as a physical and strong player with good skating who [[bodycheck|checks]] hard and is offensively effective in close proximity to the net. Following his NHL draft, he underwent surgery for chipped bones in his left elbow in August 1993.{{cite news|title=Another Islanders Rookie Hopes to Make Impact|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/09/09/sports/hockey-an-islander-rookie-hopes-to-make-impact.html|accessdate=June 17, 2010|date=September 9, 1993|author=Joe Lapointe|work=[[The New York Times]]|location=New York}} As a result, he was unable to participate in the Islanders' training camp in September and was returned to the OHL. Playing in his third season for Guelph, he improved to 28 goals and 82 points over 61 games. Bertuzzi competed for an Islanders' roster spot at their 1994 training camp, but was sent back to his junior team after going scoreless in three exhibition games.{{cite news|title=Owners, players far apart|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=qrscAAAAIBAJ&sjid=aHwEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6481,660962&dq=todd+bertuzzi&hl=en|accessdate=June 17, 2010|date=September 21, 1994|work=[[Sarasota Herald-Tribune]]|agency=Associated Press|location=Sarasota, Florida|publisher=Diane McFarlin}} During his last campaign with Guelph in [[1994–95 OHL season|1994–95]], he recorded 119 points – sixth overall in the league.{{cite web|title=1994-95 OHL League Leaders|url=http://hockeydb.com/ihdb/stats/top_league.php?lid=ohl1989&sid=1995&leaguenm=OHL|accessdate=February 27, 2011|publisher=Hockeydb.com}} His 54 goals established a single-season team record, beating [[Mike Prokopec]]'s mark, set the previous year, by two goals.{{cite web|title=Franchise All-Time Stats Per Season for Guelph Storm|url=http://www.eliteprospects.com/team_all-time_stats_per_season.php?team=552&alltime=G|accessdate=February 27, 2011|publisher=EliteProspects.com}} The Storm's forward tandem of Bertuzzi and [[Jeff O'Neill]], who finished fourth in league scoring, led the club to the best regular season record in the league. He went on to add a team-leading 33 points in 14 playoff games, en route to an OHL Finals loss to the [[Detroit Junior Red Wings]].{{cite web|title=OHL Team Standings 1994-95|url=http://www.eliteprospects.com/standings.php?league=OHL&startdate=1994|accessdate=February 27, 2011|publisher=EliteProspects.com}} After four seasons with Guelph, he left the club ranked third all-time in career points with 280, behind O'Neill and [[Martin St. Pierre (ice hockey)|Martin St. Pierre]].{{Cite web|title=Franchise All-Time Stats for Guelph Storm|url=http://www.eliteprospects.com/team_all-time_stats.php?team=552&alltime=TP|accessdate=February 27, 2011|publisher=EliteProspects.com}} ===New York Islanders (1995–98)=== Two years after his draft, Bertuzzi and the Islanders had not yet been agreed to a contract. With Bertuzzi eligible to re-enter the draft if the Islanders did not sign him by July 7, 1995, general manager [[Don Maloney]] made it apparent that he would use the team's second overall pick in the [[1995 NHL Entry Draft]] to select him again if a contract could not be agreed upon by the required date.{{cite news|title=A Reluctant Draftee May Have No Choice|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/1995-07-06/sports/17984786_1_salary-cap-islanders-todd-bertuzzi|author=Colin Stephenson|work=[[New York Daily News]]|location=New York|publisher=Mortimer Zuckerman|accessdate=August 29, 2012|date=July 6, 1995}} Moments before the midnight deadline, the Islanders were able to sign Bertuzzi to a four-year, [[United States dollar|US$]]4.6 million contract.{{cite news|title=Young Duo Is Dynamic to Milbury|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/1995-07-18/sports/17979606_1_mini-camp-islanders-don-maloney|accessdate=August 29, 2012|date=July 18, 1995|work=[[New York Daily News]]|publisher=Mortimer Zuckerman|author=Colin Stephenson}} His agent, Pat Morris, had reportedly wanted a similar deal to that of fellow Islanders prospect [[Brett Lindros]] – a five-year, $6.7 million contract signed the previous summer. During training camp in September 1995, Islanders head coach [[Mike Milbury]] heralded Bertuzzi as the team's best performing forward.{{cite news|title=Bertuzzi Comes of Age for Isle|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/1995-09-29/sports/17990008_1_todd-bertuzzi-zigmund-palffy-islanders|author=Colin Stephenson|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|location=New York|publisher=Mortimer Zuckerman|date=September 29, 1995|accessdate=August 29, 2012}} Making his NHL debut on October 7, 1995, he scored a [[Glossary of ice hockey terms#W|wrap around]] goal against goaltender [[Blaine Lacher]] in a 4–4 tie with the [[Boston Bruins]].{{cite news|title=New Top Line Shows Promise for Islanders|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/08/sports/hockey-new-top-line-shows-promise-for-islanders.html|accessdate=August 19, 2008|date=October 8, 1995 | work=[[The New York Times]] | location= New York | author=Jason Diamos}}{{cite news|title=In Depth: Todd Bertuzzi|url=http://flames.nhl.com/club/news.htm?id=454389|accessdate=February 27, 2011|date=December 26, 2008|publisher=[[Calgary Flames]]}} Beginning the season on the team's top line with [[Žigmund Pálffy]] and [[Travis Green]], Bertuzzi finished his rookie year with 18 goals and 39 points over 76 games. The [[1996–97 NHL season|following season]], Bertuzzi recorded 23 points in 64 games. The Islanders did not qualify for the playoffs in either of his two full seasons with the club, ranking second-last in the [[Eastern Conference (NHL)|Eastern Conference]] in 1995–96 and 1996–97.{{Cite web|title=1995-96 Standings|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/standings.htm?season=19951996&type=con|accessdate=March 3, 2011|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]}}{{cite web|title=1996-97 Standings|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/standings.htm?season=19961997&type=con|accessdate=March 3, 2011|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]}} Bertuzzi's playing style as a [[power forward (ice hockey)|power forward]] resulted in comparisons to former Islander [[Clark Gillies]]. As a result, the club hired Gillies to personally mentor Bertuzzi. Failing to meet lofty expectations from the club, Gillies once said of Bertuzzi, "If you're built like a freight train, you can't drive around like a Volkswagen."{{cite news|title=It's Gillies' night but ex-Isle Bertuzzi is in his heyday|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2002-12-03/sports/18217123_1_todd-bertuzzi-islanders-freight-train|accessdate=August 29, 2012|date=December 3, 2002|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|location=New York|publisher=Mortimer Zuckerman}} Feeling burdened with the pressure of playing up to the club's expectations while his offensive production diminished, he requested to be traded away at one point during the 1996–97 season. In response, Milbury, who had also taken over general manager duties the previous season, demoted Bertuzzi to the Islanders' minor league affiliate, the [[Utah Grizzlies (1995–2005)|Utah Grizzlies]] of the [[International Hockey League (1945–2001)|International Hockey League]] (IHL). Playing 13 games in the minors, he registered 10 points before being called back up to the NHL. During the [[1997–98 NHL season|1997–98 campaign]], he continued to score below his pace as a rookie. On February 6, 1998, he was traded along with defenceman [[Bryan McCabe]] and a third-round selection in the [[1998 NHL Entry Draft]] ([[Jarkko Ruutu]]) to the Vancouver Canucks in exchange for veteran forward [[Trevor Linden]]. The deal was made prior to the NHL's roster freeze in preparation for the [[Ice hockey at the 1998 Winter Olympics|1998 Winter Olympics]]. Bertuzzi and McCabe had both been widely regarded as the players of the future for New York after their respective drafts in 1993. While Milbury expressed regret at having to trade McCabe, relations between Bertuzzi and the club were strained. Welcoming the trade, Bertuzzi commented that "things weren't working out [in New York]."{{cite news|title=Isles get Linden for 2 Young Players|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50C1EFB3B590C748CDDAB0894D0494D81|accessdate=February 14, 2011|date=February 7, 1998|work=[[The New York Times]]|location=New York|first=Tarik|last=El-Bashir}} ===Vancouver Canucks (1998–2006)=== Bertuzzi immediately began producing with Vancouver, tallying 15 points in 22 games after the trade. Combined with his totals from New York, he finished with 33 points over 74 games in [[1997–98 NHL season|1997–98]]. Contrasting his strained relationship with Milbury in New York, Canucks head coach [[Mike Keenan]] has recalled his experience with Bertuzzi upon his arrival as positive: "He came as a young player and he was very open-minded about learning about the game." Similar to the Islanders, Bertuzzi joined a struggling club in Vancouver; the team finished last in the [[Western Conference (NHL)|Western Conference]] in his first two seasons after the trade.{{cite web|title=1997-98 Standings|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/standings.htm?season=19971998&type=con|accessdate=March 3, 2011|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]}}{{Cite web|title=1998-99 Standings|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/standings.htm?season=19981999&type=con|accessdate=March 3, 2011|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]}} After beginning the [[1998–99 NHL season|1998–99 season]] on the Canucks' top line,{{cite news|title=Injury-Prone Canucks Lose Mogilny|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/1998/11/22/archive/main23282.shtml|accessdate=June 4, 2008|date=November 22, 1998|publisher=[[CBS Sports]]}} Bertuzzi was limited to 32 games due to injuries, the first of which was a fractured [[tibia]]. He suffered the injury on November 1, 1998, after a shot by teammate [[Mattias Öhlund]] hit him in the leg.{{Cite news|title=Forsberg scores first goal|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0D1FFE3A5B0C708CDDA80994D0494D81|accessdate=March 3, 2011|date=November 4, 1998|location=New York|work=[[The New York Times]]}} His season was later ended with a torn [[anterior cruciate ligament]] (ACL) in his left knee, suffered during a game on March 5, 1999. He recorded 8 goals and 16 points in 1998–99. In the off-season, Bertuzzi became a [[restricted free agent]] and was re-signed by the Canucks to a two-year contract in September 1999. The deal was reported by ''[[The Vancouver Sun]]'' to be worth a little over $2 million.{{cite news|title=Canucks re-sign Bertuzzi|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=NewsLibrary&p_multi=APAB&d_place=APAB&p_theme=newslibrary2&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0F8A1E2FC780BFD5&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|accessdate=March 3, 2011|date=September 3, 1999|agency=[[Associated Press]]}} Returning from injury the following season, Bertuzzi emerged as one of the Canucks' best offensive contributors, finishing with 25 goals (second on the team to [[Markus Näslund]]){{Cite web|title=Vancouver Canucks - Goals 1999-2000|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/playerstats.htm?fetchKey=20002VANSASAll&sort=goals&viewName=summary|accessdate=March 3, 2011|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]}} and 50 points in [[1999–2000 NHL season|1999–2000]]. At the end of the season, he received the team's [[Most Exciting Player Award]], as voted by the fans. He received the distinction three more times during his career with the Canucks from 2002 to 2004).{{cite book|title=Vancouver Canucks Media Guide 2008–09|publisher=[[Vancouver Canucks]]|year=2008}} Meanwhile, the Canucks began improving as a team, finishing four points out of a playoff spot in the West in 2000.{{Cite web|title=1999-2000 Standings|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/standings.htm?season=19992000&type=con|accessdate=March 3, 2011|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]}} The following season, Bertuzzi recorded his first career NHL [[hat trick]], recording all three goals on the [[power play (sport)|power play]] against [[San Jose Sharks]] goaltender [[Evgeni Nabokov]] in a 6–3 win on December 30, 2000.{{cite news|title=Canucks vs. Sharks|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores100/100365/100365348.htm|accessdate=March 3, 2011|date=December 31, 2000|work=[[USA Today]]|publisher=Gannett Company|location=McLean, Virginia}} Bertuzzi recorded a second consecutive 25-goal season in [[2000–01 NHL season|2000–01]], adding 30 assists for 55 points, third in team scoring behind Näslund and [[Andrew Cassels]]. His -18 [[Plus-minus (ice hockey)|plus-minus]] rating, however, was a team-worst.{{cite web|title=Vancouver Canucks 2000–2001 Total Points|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/playerstats.htm?fetchKey=20012VANSASAll&sort=points&viewName=summary|accessdate=February 14, 2011|publisher=National Hockey League}} The Canucks continued to improve, qualifying for the post-season for the first time in five years. Entering the [[2001 Stanley Cup playoffs|2001 playoffs]] as the final and eighth [[seed (sports)|seed]] in the West, they were eliminated in the first round by the [[Colorado Avalanche]]. Bertuzzi scored two goals and two assists over four games in his first NHL post-season appearance. In the off-season, Bertuzzi filed for [[salary arbitration]] after initially failing to come to terms on a new contract with the Canucks.{{cite news|title=Hockey|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5VgzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=c3ADAAAAIBAJ&pg=4634,4351705&dq=todd+bertuzzi+contract&hl=en|accessdate=March 3, 2011|date=July 27, 2001|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|publisher=Block Communications|location=Pittsburgh}} Both sides avoided arbitration by agreeing to a three-year deal on July 26, 2001.{{cite web|title=Todd Bertuzzi|url=http://tsn.ca/nhl/teams/players/bio/?id=943|accessdate=March 3, 2011|publisher=[[The Sports Network]]}} [[Image:Todd Bertuzzi (Canucks).jpg|thumb|left|Bertuzzi spent seven-and-a-half seasons with the Canucks.]] In the first month of the [[2001–02 NHL season|2001–02 season]], Bertuzzi received an automatic 10-game suspension from the league (forfeiting $118,557 in salary) after leaving the bench to help teammate [[Ed Jovanovski]] in a [[fighting in ice hockey|fight]]. The incident occurred during a game against the Colorado Avalanche in which opposing coach [[Bob Hartley]] sent [[enforcer (ice hockey)|enforcer]] [[Scott Parker (ice hockey)|Scott Parker]] onto the ice as the [[extra attacker]] during a [[delayed penalty]]. Parker proceeded to physically engage Jovanovski, at which point Bertuzzi left the bench to help his teammate. Vancouver struggled with him out of the lineup, winning 3 games during the 10-game span. Two months after returning from suspension, Bertuzzi went 15 consecutive games with at least a point, scoring 7 goals and 12 assists from January 3 – February 4, 2002. The streak tied [[Petr Nedvěd]] for the longest in Canucks history. During that span, in a game on January 9, Canucks head coach Marc Crawford replaced [[Andrew Cassels]] with [[Brendan Morrison]], marking the beginning of what was considered by many to be the most effective line combination in the league for several seasons.{{cite news|title=Hat Tricksters|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1027938/index.htm|accessdate=August 13, 2009|date=January 13, 2003|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|publisher=Stephen Walsh|location=New York}}{{cite news|url=http://www.canada.com/theprovince/news/sports/story.html?id=7707b0e2-2f29-4893-a435-8b0fe6bdf7d0 |title=Emotional time for Naslund |date=November 27, 2007 |accessdate=July 25, 2008 |work=[[The Province]] |location=Vancouver |publisher=Postmedia Network |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628213746/http://www.canada.com/theprovince/news/sports/story.html?id=7707b0e2-2f29-4893-a435-8b0fe6bdf7d0 |archivedate=June 28, 2011 |df= }}{{cite news|title=Naslund is still a Canuck at heart |url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/blogs/jimhughson/2008/11/naslund-is-still-a-canuck-at-heart.html |accessdate=November 19, 2008 |date=November 16, 2008 |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628220203/http://www.cbc.ca/sports/blogs/jimhughson/2008/11/naslund-is-still-a-canuck-at-heart.html |archivedate=June 28, 2011 }}{{Cite web|title=Chemistry lesson works in Vancouver|url=http://www.nhl.com/intheslot/read/indepth/naslund/line.html|accessdate=October 16, 2010|date=February 19, 2004|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]|author=Karl Samuelsson|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628182052/http://www.nhl.com/intheslot/read/indepth/naslund/line.html|archivedate=June 28, 2011|df=mdy-all}} Bertuzzi had emerged as an effective power forward, able to use his size and strength to position himself in front of the net, with good stickhandling ability. According to Canucks assistant coach [[Jack McIlhargey]], Bertuzzi's skill set favourably complemented Näslund's goal-scoring and Morrison's playmaking abilities. The trio were dubbed by Vancouver media as the "[[West Coast Express (ice hockey)|West Coast Express]]", named after [[West Coast Express|the city's commuter rail service]] of the same name. Late in the 2001–02 season, Bertuzzi recorded his second career hat-trick on March 19, 2002, during a win against the [[New York Rangers]]. He scored his first two goals of the game against [[Dan Blackburn]] and his third into an [[empty net goal|empty net]]. Despite missing ten games from his suspension, Bertuzzi finished the [[2001–02 NHL season|2001–02 season]] third in league-scoring with 85 points, behind Näslund and [[Calgary Flames]] forward [[Jarome Iginla]]. His 1.18 points-per-game average ranked second in the NHL behind [[Mario Lemieux]], who played 48 fewer games than Bertuzzi.{{cite web|title=Points Per Game|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/playerstats.htm?fetchKey=20022ALLSASAll&sort=points&viewName=points|accessdate=October 17, 2010|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]}} He also improved his plus-minus rating by 39 points from the previous season, finishing a career-high +21. Although the Canucks were the league's highest scoring team,{{cite web|title=Goals/Game 2001–02|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/teamstats.htm?fetchKey=20022ALLAAAAll&sort=avgGoalsPerGame&viewName=summary|accessdate=March 3, 2011|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]}} they finished with the final seed in the West for the [[2002 Stanley Cup playoffs|2002 playoffs]], ranking eighth in their conference.{{cite web|title=2001-02 Standings|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/standings.htm?season=20012002&type=con|accessdate=March 3, 2011|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]}} Facing the [[Detroit Red Wings]] in the opening round, they were eliminated in six games. Bertuzzi recorded four points in the series. The following season, Bertuzzi appeared in his first [[2003 NHL All-Star Game|NHL All-Star Game]]. He was joined by fellow Canucks Markus Näslund, defenceman Ed Jovanovski and head coach Marc Crawford,{{cite news|title=East-West matchup has distinct Northern flavour|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/hockey/2003/all_star/news/2003/02/01/east_west_ap/|accessdate=March 3, 2011|date=February 1, 2003|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]}} helping the Western Conference to a 6–5 [[shootout (ice hockey)|shootout]] win against the East.{{cite news|title=Dandy Dany|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/hockey/2003/all_star/news/2003/02/02/all_star_ap/|accessdate=March 3, 2011|date=February 2, 2003|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|location=New York|publisher=Stephen Walsh}} He played on a line with Näslund and [[Peter Forsberg]]. Later in the season, he scored his third career hat-trick on March 17, 2003, scoring three goals against [[Ron Tugnutt]] in a game against the [[Dallas Stars]]. He finished the season with career-highs of 46 goals (third in the league), 51 assists and 97 points (fifth in the league).{{Cite web|title=2002–03 League Leaders|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/playerstats.htm?fetchKey=20032ALLSASAll&sort=points&viewName=summary|accessdate=February 28, 2011|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]}} His 25 power play goals led the NHL and tied [[Pavel Bure]] for the Canucks' single-season record.{{cite web|title=2002–03 League Leaders - Powerplay goals|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/playerstats.htm?fetchKey=20032ALLSASAll&sort=powerPlayGoals&viewName=summary|accessdate=February 28, 2011|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]}}{{Cite web|title=Vancouver Canucks Single-Season Leaders - Powerplay goals|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/careerstats.htm?fetchKey=00002VANSAHAll&sort=powerPlayGoals&viewName=careerLeadersSingleSeasonForTeam|accessdate=February 28, 2011|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]}} Linemates Näslund and Morrison also recorded personal bests with 104 and 71 points, respectively.{{cite web|title=Brendan Morrison|url=http://tsn.ca/nhl/teams/players/bio/?id=219|accessdate=March 24, 2011|publisher=[[The Sports Network]]}}{{cite web|title=Markus Naslund|url=http://tsn.ca/nhl/teams/players/bio/?id=350|accessdate=March 24, 2011|publisher=[[The Sports Network]]}} Meanwhile, the Canucks emerged as a top team in the West. Losing the [[Northwest Division (NHL)|Northwest Division]] title to the Avalanche by one point in the regular season, they finished as the fourth seed in their conference.{{cite web|title=2002-2003 Standings|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/standings.htm?season=20022003|accessdate=March 24, 2011|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]}} After going down three-games-to-one in the opening round against the [[St. Louis Blues]], Vancouver won three straight games to advance to the second round. Facing the [[Minnesota Wild]], the Canucks gave up their own three-games-to-one series lead and were eliminated in seven games. During the series, Bertuzzi had reportedly walked by the [[Xcel Energy Center]] box office and told Wild fans they would not need their Game 6 tickets because Minnesota would be eliminated by then. In another on-ice incident, he skated by the opposing bench during Game 7 when the Canucks were winning 2–0, telling Wild players to "get [their] golf clubs".{{cite news|title=Stanley Cup report May 14, 2003|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/penguins/20030514cuplog0514p7.asp|accessdate=March 3, 2011|date=May 14, 2003|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|location=Pittsburgh|publisher=Block Communications|first1=Dave|last1=Molinari}} Despite his successful regular season, Bertuzzi struggled to score in the playoffs, recording 6 points in 14 games. In the off-season, Bertuzzi was named with Näslund to the [[NHL All-Star Team|NHL First All-Star Team]]. [[Image:Markus Naslund and Todd Bertuzzi.jpg|thumb|right|Näslund and Bertuzzi (right) formed a prolific duo for several years on the Canucks' top line.]] With Bertuzzi entering the final year of his contract, the Canucks began negotiating a contract extension prior to the [[2003–04 NHL season|2003–04 season]]. Despite Bertuzzi's agent, Pat Morris, declaring that they would cease negotiations once the season began,{{cite news|title=Bertuzzi's new deal settles things down in Vancouver|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2003/hockey/nhl/10/26/glance/|accessdate=March 3, 2011|date=October 26, 2003|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|publisher=Stephen Walsh|location=New York}} Bertuzzi signed a four-year, $27.8 million deal with the Canucks on October 23, 2003. The contract took effect immediately, erasing the last year on his previous contract, and included a $3 million signing bonus ($2.5 million paid in the first year and $500,000 in the second). The deal paid him $4.3 million the first year, $6.633 million the second year and $6.933 million for the third and fourth years.{{cite news|title=Money well spent in Vancouver|url=http://insider.espn.go.com/insider/story?id=1647773|accessdate=March 3, 2011|date=October 27, 2003|publisher=[[ESPN]]}} In January 2004, Bertuzzi was voted by league fans to the starting lineup of the [[2004 NHL All-Star Game|NHL All-Star Game]]. Representing the Western Conference alongside Näslund and Canucks head coach Marc Crawford, they were defeated by the East 6–4. Bertuzzi had two assists while playing on a line with Näslund and [[Joe Sakic]].{{cite news|title=West teammates take liking to MVP Sakic|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/hockey/allstar/2004-02-08-sakic-mvp_x.htm|accessdate=March 3, 2011|date=February 8, 2004|publisher=''[[USA Today]]''|first1=Kevin|last1=Allen}} Nearing the end of the [[2003–04 NHL season|2003–04 season]], Bertuzzi was indefinitely suspended by the NHL for punching Colorado Avalanche forward [[Steve Moore (ice hockey)|Steve Moore]] from behind during a game on March 8, 2004. His actions were a retaliation to a hit from Moore on Näslund during a previous game. Sitting out the remainder of the regular season and playoffs due to his suspension, he finished 2003–04 with 60 points over 69 games. Vancouver replaced Bertuzzi on the team's top line with [[Matt Cooke]]{{cite news|title=How Matt's gloss wore off |url=http://www.canada.com/story_print.html?id=cbfa0d4c-2132-4141-8b5c-aa773b0c9382&sponsor= |accessdate=March 24, 2011 |date=February 27, 2008 |work=[[The Province]] |location=Vancouver |publisher=Postmedia Network |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121109090854/http://www.canada.com/story_print.html?id=cbfa0d4c-2132-4141-8b5c-aa773b0c9382&sponsor= |archivedate=November 9, 2012 |df= }} and went on to their first Northwest Division title,{{cite web|title=2003-2004 Standings|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/standings.htm?season=20032004&type=DIV|accessdate=March 24, 2011|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]}} before being eliminated in the first round of the [[2004 Stanley Cup playoffs|2004 playoffs]] by the Calgary Flames. Inactive in [[2004–05 NHL season|2004–05]] due to the [[2004–05 NHL lockout|players lockout]] and his ongoing suspension, which had been extended internationally, Bertuzzi returned to the Canucks in [[2005–06 NHL season|2005–06]], as the league ended his playing ban. He recorded 25 goals and 71 points, including two hat tricks (November 13, 2005, against the Detroit Red Wings and January 14, 2006, against the New York Islanders). Though he ranked third in team scoring, Crawford has recalled that by the end of the season, Näslund and Bertuzzi had been eclipsed by [[Daniel Sedin|Daniel]] and [[Henrik Sedin]] as the team's offensive leaders.{{cite news|title=Surprised by Sedin? You shouldn't be |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/columns/story?columnist=lebrun_pierre&id=4883674 |accessdate=October 17, 2010 |date=February 3, 2010 |publisher=[[ESPN]] |last=LeBrun |first=Pierre |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203002036/http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/columns/story?columnist=lebrun_pierre&id=4883674 |archivedate=February 3, 2014 |df= }} There was speculation that the effects of the Steve Moore incident, which included assault charges and constant media coverage, were negatively affecting his play. While on the road, he was consistently heckled and booed by fans throughout the NHL.{{cite news|last=Diamos|first=Jason|title=Rangers almost measure up with Canucks|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/14/sports/hockey/14rangers.html?n=Top/News/Sports/Hockey/National%20Hockey%20League/Vancouver%20Canucks|work=[[The New York Times]]|location=New York|accessdate=June 4, 2008|date=December 14, 2005}}{{cite news|title=Canada names Bertuzzi to Olympic team|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/22/sports/hockey/22olympics.html?pagewanted=print|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=June 4, 2008|date=December 22, 2005 | first=Lee | last=Jenkins}}{{cite web|title=Great and ghastly|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Hockey/NHL/Edmonton/2005/10/09/1255331-sun.html|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]|accessdate=June 4, 2008|date=October 9, 2005}} Näslund, a close friend of Bertuzzi's, later expressed sympathy for him, saying in a 2008 interview, "It still bothers me what Todd has had to go through...There's no question he was standing up for me...it all went too far."{{Cite news|title=New beginning, old concerns for Naslund |url=http://www.canada.com/theprovince/news/sports/story.html?id=5d6b3ef6-25fb-41a3-945d-e9a5a572bbcb |accessdate=September 26, 2008 |date=September 26, 2008 |work=[[The Province]] |publisher=Postmedia News |location=Vancouver |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080930022422/http://www.canada.com/theprovince/news/sports/story.html?id=5d6b3ef6-25fb-41a3-945d-e9a5a572bbcb |archivedate=September 30, 2008 |df= }} Beyond the negative impact on Bertuzzi's individual play, the media speculated that the fallout from the Moore incident had become a distraction to the organization as a whole.{{cite web|title=Oilers may lose Pronger, Canucks trade Bertuzzi|url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Canada/20060624/bertuzzi_trade_060624/|publisher=[[CTV News]]|accessdate=June 4, 2008|date=June 24, 2006}} Compounding the situation in Vancouver, the Canucks had missed the playoffs for the first time in four years. As such, general manager [[Dave Nonis]] spent the off-season making significant changes to the Canucks lineup. On June 23, 2006, he traded Bertuzzi to the [[Florida Panthers]], along with goaltender [[Alex Auld]] and defenceman [[Bryan Allen (ice hockey)|Bryan Allen]], in exchange for goaltender [[Roberto Luongo]], defenceman [[Lukáš Krajíček]] and a sixth-round selection in the [[2006 NHL Entry Draft]] ([[Sergei Shirokov]]).{{Cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/news/story?id=2498872|title=Canucks swap Bertuzzi for Luongo in multiplayer deal|accessdate=November 21, 2007|date=July 23, 2006|publisher=[[ESPN]]}} After seven-and-a-half seasons with the Canucks, Bertuzzi left the club ranked seventh all-time among [[Vancouver Canucks#Franchise scoring leaders|franchise scoring leaders]] with 449 points.{{cite web|title=Career Leaders Per Team - Points|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/careerstats.htm?fetchKey=00002VANSAHAll&sort=points&viewName=careerLeadersForTeam|accessdate=February 28, 2011|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]}} ===Florida, Detroit, and Anaheim (2006–08)=== Instrumental in facilitating the trade to Florida was Bertuzzi's positive relationship with Panthers general manager Mike Keenan, who was his first coach in Vancouver.{{cite news|title=Flipping GMs a regular business for Panthers|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nhl/story/9636565|accessdate=March 24, 2011|date=September 3, 2006|publisher=[[CBS Sports]]|author=Wes Goldstein}} Debuting with the Panthers on October 6, 2006, Bertuzzi scored a goal and three assists in an 8–3 win against the Boston Bruins.{{cite news|title=Panthers 8, Bruins 3|url=http://panthers.nhl.com/club/recap.htm?id=2006020016|accessdate=March 24, 2011|date=October 6, 2006|publisher=[[Florida Panthers]]|agency=Associated Press|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120130084528/http://panthers.nhl.com/club/recap.htm?id=2006020016|archivedate=January 30, 2012|df=mdy-all}} He appeared in six more games for Florida, notching seven points total, before being sidelined with [[back spasms]]. After being diagnosed with a [[herniated disc]] in early-November, Bertuzzi opted for surgery, which kept him out of the lineup for five months. While recovering, the Panthers dealt him to the Detroit Red Wings at the [[National Hockey League trade deadline|trade deadline]] in exchange for forward prospect [[Shawn Matthias]] and conditional draft picks. Bertuzzi was in the last year of his contract with no guarantee he would re-sign with Florida in the off-season.{{cite news|title=Red Wings add toughness with Bertuzzi in trade with Panthers|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/hockey/nhl/2007-02-27-670995085_x.htm|accessdate=March 24, 2011|date=February 27, 2007|work=[[USA Today]]|location=McLean, Virginia|publisher=Gannett Company|first=Larry|last=Lage}} [[File:Todd Bertuzzi (Ducks).jpg|thumb|right|Bertuzzi spent one season with the Ducks in 2007–08.]] Bertuzzi returned to action on March 22, 2007, debuting with his new team in a 2–1 shootout loss to the [[Columbus Blue Jackets]].{{cite news|title=Blue Jackets 2, Red Wings 1 SO|url=http://redwings.nhl.com/club/recap.htm?id=2006021108|accessdate=March 24, 2011|date=March 22, 2007|publisher=[[Detroit Red Wings]]|agency=Associated Press|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309051721/http://redwings.nhl.com/club/recap.htm?id=2006021108|archivedate=March 9, 2012|df=mdy-all}} Eight days later, he scored his first goal as a Red Wing in a 4–3 shootout loss to the [[Dallas Stars]].{{cite news|title=Stars 2, Red Wings 1 SO|url=http://redwings.nhl.com/club/recap.htm?id=2006021162|accessdate=March 24, 2011|publisher=[[Detroit Red Wings]]|agency=Associated Press|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311015500/http://redwings.nhl.com/club/recap.htm?id=2006021162|archivedate=March 11, 2012|df=mdy-all}} On April 7, he suffered a neck injury that kept him out of the lineup for the last game of the regular season and the first two games of the [[2007 Stanley Cup playoffs|2007 playoffs]]. He finished the campaign with 11 points in 15 games split between Florida and Detroit. During the playoffs, the Red Wings advanced to the Western Conference Finals, where they lost in six games to the [[Anaheim Ducks]], who went on to win the [[Stanley Cup]]. Bertuzzi recorded 7 points in 16 playoff games. Becoming an [[unrestricted free agent]] in the off-season, Bertuzzi agreed to a two-year, $8 million contract with the Anaheim Ducks on July 2, 2007. Signing him was Ducks general manager [[Brian Burke (ice hockey)|Brian Burke]], who had served as the Canucks general manager during Bertuzzi's time in Vancouver.{{cite news|title=Bertuzzi tries to revive career with champion Ducks|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/news/story?id=2924157|accessdate=March 3, 2011|date=July 2, 2007|publisher=[[ESPN]]}} Bertuzzi had reportedly been in negotiations to re-sign with Detroit, but the club only wanted a one-year deal. Playing the Red Wings in the Ducks' first game of the regular season on October 3, 2007, he registered a goal and an assist in a 3–2 shootout loss.{{cite news|title=Ducks 3, Red Wings 2 SO|url=http://ducks.nhl.com/club/recap.htm?id=2007020004|accessdate=March 24, 2011|date=October 3, 2007|publisher=[[Anaheim Ducks]]|agency=Associated Press|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120213192917/http://ducks.nhl.com/club/recap.htm?id=2007020004|archivedate=February 13, 2012|df=mdy-all}} In the first month of the [[2007–08 NHL season|2007–08 campaign]], he suffered a concussion and was sidelined for 14 games in October and November 2007. Bertuzzi returned to the lineup in time for the Ducks' away game against the Canucks on November 27, which marked his first NHL game in Vancouver since being traded away.{{cite news|title=Bert's return underwhelming|url=http://www.canada.com/topics/sports/story.html?id=3e8575f2-75f8-4afe-88db-fddcc89aa06c|accessdate=February 28, 2011|date=November 28, 2007|work=[[The Province]]|location=Vancouver|publisher=Postmedia Network|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628221550/http://www.canada.com/topics/sports/story.html?id=3e8575f2-75f8-4afe-88db-fddcc89aa06c|archivedate=June 28, 2011|df=mdy-all}} Bertuzzi was received warmly by Canucks fans, as the Ducks lost the game 4–0. Playing in 68 contests over the season, he registered 40 points with Anaheim. Entering the [[2008 Stanley Cup playoffs|2008 playoffs]] as the defending champions, the Ducks were eliminated in the first round four games to two by the [[Dallas Stars]]. In six playoff contests, Bertuzzi recorded two assists. [[Image:Todd Bertuzzi Calgary.jpg|thumb|left|Bertuzzi signed with the Calgary Flames in 2008.]] ===Calgary Flames (2008–09)=== During the subsequent summer, several Ducks players were set to become free agents, including high-profile forward [[Corey Perry]]. Requiring additional [[salary cap]] space to make room for defenceman [[Scott Niedermayer]], who announced he was returning for another season, Bertuzzi was placed on [[waivers (NHL)|unconditional waivers]] with the intention of buying out the remaining year on his contract.{{cite news|title=Ducks place Todd Bertuzzi on waivers|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/hockey/story/2008/06/27/bertuzzi-ducks.html|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=July 7, 2008|date=June 27, 2008}} Addressing Bertuzzi's buy out with the media, Burke asserted that he "believe[d] [Bertuzzi] can still play at the NHL level," and that the Ducks were merely "handcuffed by [their] salary cap situation." Bertuzzi once again became an unrestricted free agent and signed a one-year, $1.95 million contract with the Calgary Flames on July 7, 2008.{{cite news|title=Flames sign Bertuzzi for one year|url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/jul/07/flames-sign-bertuzzi-one-year/|accessdate=September 12, 2008|date=July 7, 2008|agency=Associated Press|work=[[Rocky Mountain News]]|location=Denver, Colorado|publisher=John Temple|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080803224012/http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/jul/07/flames-sign-bertuzzi-one-year/ |archivedate = August 3, 2008}} Joining Calgary, he was reunited with Flames coach Mike Keenan. Before the start of the [[2008–09 NHL season|2008–09 season]], Bertuzzi switched jersey numbers from 4 to 7, in honour of his boyhood idol, [[Phil Esposito]].{{Cite web|title=Bertuzzi honours Espo with number selection|url=http://www.faceoff.com/story.html?id=2e9b304a-c85b-46e6-84fe-0c8f9e8df031&add_feed_url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.faceoff.com%2Ftopstories.atom|accessdate=September 12, 2008|date=September 10, 2008|publisher=[[CanWest News Service]]}} The numbers 44, which Bertuzzi wore in New York, Vancouver and Detroit, and 4, which he wore in Anaheim, were already taken in Calgary. Bertuzzi scored his first goal with the Flames, deflecting a [[Dion Phaneuf]] shot, on October 12, 2008, in a 5-4 overtime loss to the Vancouver Canucks.{{cite news|title=Canucks beat Flames 5-4 in OT|url=http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/news/story.html?id=9d843230-24f2-4767-8973-1b7421b1c12a|accessdate=October 18, 2008|date=October 12, 2008|work=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|publisher=Postmedia Network|location=Vancouver|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081015042111/http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/news/story.html?id=9d843230-24f2-4767-8973-1b7421b1c12a|archivedate=October 15, 2008|df=mdy-all}} While initial fan reaction to Bertuzzi was negative due to his previous role with the division-rival Canucks, as well as his reputation following the Steve Moore incident, he was eventually accepted in Calgary. In January 2009, he missed five games due to a back injury. Several months later, he was sidelined again with a knee injury and underwent [[arthroscopic surgery]] to repair damaged cartilage on March 3, 2009.{{cite news|title=Bertuzzi has surgery|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/news.htm?id=412291|accessdate=March 24, 2011|date=March 4, 2009|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]}} Missing 11 games, he returned in time for the [[2009 Stanley Cup playoffs|2009 playoffs]], where the Flames were eliminated by the [[Chicago Blackhawks]] in the opening round. He finished his only season in Calgary with 44 points in 66 regular season games, while adding a goal and an assist in six playoff contests. ===Return to Detroit (2009–2014)=== On August 18, 2009, Bertuzzi re-joined the Red Wings by accepting a one-year contract with the club worth $1.5 million.{{Cite web|title=Wings, Bertuzzi agree on 1-year contract, pending physical|url=http://tsn.ca/nhl/story/?id=288074|date=August 10, 2009|publisher=[[The Sports Network]]}} He recorded 44 points (18 goals and 26 assists) in [[2009–10 NHL season|2009–10]], ranking fifth in team scoring.{{cite web|title=2009-2010 Red Wings - All Skaters - Points|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/playerstats.htm?fetchKey=20102DETSASAll&sort=points&viewName=assists|accessdate=March 24, 2011|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]}} During the second round of the [[2010 Stanley Cup playoffs|2010 playoffs]], Bertuzzi recorded a career-high five-point contest (a goal and four assists) in a Game 4 victory against the San Jose Sharks.{{cite news|title=Big Bert enjoys biggest day of his career|url=http://redwings.nhl.com/club/news.htm?id=528360|accessdate=March 24, 2011|date=May 7, 2010|publisher=[[Detroit Red Wings]]}} Bertuzzi finished with a playoffs career-high 11 points in 12 games. In the off-season, Bertuzzi signed a two-year, $3.875 million contract extension with the Red Wings on June 16, 2010.{{cite news|title=Red Wings Agree to Two-Year Deal with Bertuzzi |url=https://www.tsn.ca/nhl/story/?id=324855 |accessdate=June 16, 2010 |date=June 16, 2010 |publisher=The Sports Network |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qXtyUd4N?url=http://www.tsn.ca/nhl/story/?id=324855 |archivedate=June 17, 2010 |df=mdy }} During the [[2010–11 NHL season|2010–11 season]], he appeared in his [[List of NHL players with 1000 games played|1,000th NHL game]] on February 20, 2011, against the Minnesota Wild. Bertuzzi scored a shootout goal to help Detroit win the game 2–1.{{cite news|title=Todd Bertuzzi in 1,000th game gives Red Wings win vs. Wild|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/hockey/nhl/2011-02-20-red-wings-beat-wild_N.htm|accessdate=February 21, 2011|date=February 20, 2011|work=[[USA Today]]|location=McLean, Virginia|publisher=Gannett Company}} Dressing for 81 games that season, he ranked seventh in team scoring with 45 points (16 goals and 29 assists).{{cite web|title=2010-11 Detroit Red Wings (NHL)|url=http://www.hockeydb.com/ihdb/stats/leagues/seasons/teams/0000342011.html|accessdate=November 24, 2011|publisher=Hockeydb.com}} During the [[2011 Stanley Cup playoffs|2011 playoffs]], he added 6 points (2 goals and 4 assists) over 11 games as the Red Wings were eliminated in the second round by the San Jose Sharks. On February 23, 2012 Bertuzzi re-signed with the Red Wings for $4.15 million over two years.{{Cite news|url=https://www.macombdaily.com/sports/detroit-red-wings-re-sign-todd-bertuzzi-to-two-year/article_82282084-47e9-5be2-853c-32f4e963385f.html|title=Detroit Red Wings re-sign Todd Bertuzzi to two-year deal|last=Pleiness|first=Chuck|date=February 23, 2012|work=Macomb Daily|access-date=October 31, 2018}} He dressed for seven games in the lockout-shortened 2012-2013 regular season due to injuries, producing three points, and was held pointless over six games in the playoffs. In the 2013-2014 season he played 59 games and produced 16 points, but was a healthy scratch 15 times; he played one playoff game without a point.{{Cite news|url=https://octopusthrower.com/2014/06/08/re-sign-re-sign-todd-bertuzzi/|title=To Re-Sign Or Not Re-Sign: Todd Bertuzzi|date=2014-06-08|work=Octopus Thrower|access-date=2018-10-31|language=en-US}} During his time with Detroit, he earned praise from head coach [[Mike Babcock]] and teammates for adapting his playing style to be more defensively responsible. Bertuzzi credited the influence of teammates [[Pavel Datsyuk]] and [[Henrik Zetterberg]], both successful two-way players in the league.{{cite news|title=Todd Bertuzzi's emphasis on defense draws praise from Red Wings teammates|url=http://www.mlive.com/redwings/index.ssf/2010/11/todd_bertuzzis_emphasis_on_def.html|accessdate=February 14, 2011|date=November 13, 2010|publisher=Michigan Live}} ===Binghamton Senators Tryout and Retirement (2015)=== On January 9, 2015 he signed a professional tryout contract with the [[Ottawa Senators]] [[American Hockey League|AHL]] affiliate the [[Binghamton Senators]] in hopes to get a contract with Ottawa. Bertuzzi was released from his professional tryout offer with Binghamton on January 21, 2015, after posting no points and a minus-3 rating in his 2 games played with the Senators. He subsequently retired that year.{{cite web|title=Bertuzzi catches the coaching bug|url=http://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/2016/01/15/bertuzzi-catches-coaching-bug-after-retirement-bringing-his-oakland-grizzlies-from-michigan-to-peterboroughs-midget-tournament-of-champions-this-weekend|publisher=The Peterborough Examiner}} ==International play== Bertuzzi debuted internationally for [[Canada men's national ice hockey team|Team Canada]] at the [[1998 Men's World Ice Hockey Championships|1998 World Championships]] in [[Switzerland]]. He was among the youngest players selected to the team, along with Canucks teammate Bryan McCabe and [[Chicago Blackhawks]] forward [[Eric Dazé]], who were all born in 1975 (third-string goaltender [[Christian Bronsard]] was two years younger, but did not play in any games).{{cite web|title=1998 IIHF World Men's Championship|url=http://hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/4726/la_id/1.htm|accessdate=February 28, 2011|publisher=[[Hockey Canada]]}} In six games, he recorded three points, as Canada failed to qualify for the medal rounds. Two years later, Bertuzzi competed at the [[2000 Men's World Ice Hockey Championships|2000 World Championships]] in [[St. Petersburg, Russia]]. One of five Canucks players chosen to the national team, he was joined by [[Adrian Aucoin]], Ed Jovanovski, Brendan Morrison and [[Peter Schaefer (ice hockey)|Peter Schaefer]].{{Cite web|title=Team Canada Roster|url=http://www.iihf.com/hockey/x/9900/wsa00/cs/pg000093.htm|accessdate=February 28, 2011|publisher=[[International Ice Hockey Federation]]}} His second tournament appearance was more productive, as he scored nine points in nine games – first among Canadian players and fourth overall –{{cite web|title=Scoring Leaders|url=http://www.iihf.com/hockey/x/9900/wsa00/gs/pg000026.htm|accessdate=February 28, 2011|publisher=[[International Ice Hockey Federation]]}} while also leading the tournament in penalty minutes with 47.{{cite web|title=Most Penalized Players|url=http://www.iihf.com/hockey/x/9900/wsa00/gs/pg000023.htm|accessdate=February 28, 2011|publisher=[[International Ice Hockey Federation]]}} Canada did not medal, losing to [[Finland men's national ice hockey team|Finland]] in the bronze medal game by a 2–1 score.{{cite web|title=Final Round|url=http://www.iihf.com/hockey/x/9900/wsa00/cs/pg000027.htm|accessdate=February 28, 2011|publisher=[[International Ice Hockey Federation]]}} His 63 total penalty minutes from both tournament appearances set an all-time Canadian record for World Championship competitors since 1977 (when Canada resumed competing in the tournament). In December 2005, Bertuzzi was controversially selected to play for Team Canada at the [[2006 Winter Olympics]] in [[Turin, Italy]]. His inclusion, along with that of [[Dany Heatley]] and [[Shane Doan]],{{#tag:ref|Heatley was on probation after pleading guilty to [[vehicular homicide]] in 2005, while Doan had been previously accused of uttering a racial slur at a [[Québécois people|Francophone]] referee during an NHL game.{{cite news|title=The List of Shame?|url=http://www.canada.com/story_print.html?id=c0e31e6e-b2b5-48a4-ba0e-ee5a0b8cda95&sponsor=|accessdate=June 8, 2011|date=December 23, 2005|work=[[National Post]]|location=Toronto|publisher=CanWest MediaWorks|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110112948/http://www.canada.com/story_print.html?id=c0e31e6e-b2b5-48a4-ba0e-ee5a0b8cda95&sponsor=|archivedate=November 10, 2012|df=mdy-all}}|group=notes}} was discussed at length by the [[Canadian Olympic Committee]] (COC). The committee had concerns stemming from the Steve Moore incident and Bertuzzi's probationary status,{{Cite web|url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/CTVNewsAt11/20051221/hockey051221/|title=Canadian Olympic Committee approves Bertuzzi|accessdate=November 21, 2007|date=December 25, 2005|publisher=[[CTV News]]}} but subsequently approved his representation of Canada at the Olympics. According to a [[Canadian Press]] article, "''[COC president] Chambers said the [unusual meeting] was prompted by some media concerns raised over the three athletes participating in the Games. The fact it took the committee so long to approve the list means there was some debate.''"{{Cite news|url=https://www.tsn.ca/nhl/news_story/?ID=147944&hubname=nhl|title=COC approves Men's hockey roster|publisher=[[The Sports Network]]|accessdate=November 21, 2007|date=December 22, 2005|agency=Canadian Press |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070929160934/http://www.tsn.ca/nhl/news_story/?ID=147944&hubname=nhl |archivedate=September 29, 2007 }} Bertuzzi went on to post three points (all assists) at the 2006 Olympics, tying for second in team scoring with nine other players.{{cite web|title=Player Statistics by Team|url=http://www.iihf.com/Hydra/OG06/data/iihf/output/xml/11/IHM400000_83_70_0.pdf|accessdate=February 28, 2011|publisher=[[International Ice Hockey Federation]]}} Canada failed to advance past the quarterfinal, losing to [[Russia national men's ice hockey team|Russia]] by a 2–0 score.{{cite web|title=2006 Winter Olympics|url=http://www.iihf.com/Hydra/OG06/IIHF_Core/jsp/content/web_output/index.jsp@compId=11|accessdate=February 28, 2011|publisher=[[International Ice Hockey Federation]]}} They finished in seventh place overall after winning gold at the previous [[Ice hockey at the 2002 Winter Olympics|Winter Olympics in 2002]]. ==Steve Moore incident== {{main|Todd Bertuzzi–Steve Moore incident}} On February 16, 2004, during a game between Vancouver and Colorado, Avalanche center [[Steve Moore (ice hockey)|Steve Moore]] checked Markus Näslund in the head, causing a minor concussion and a bone chip in his elbow.{{cite news|title=Steve Moore's victim impact statement|url=http://swo.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20041223/moore_statement_041223?hub=TorontoNewHome|accessdate=March 3, 2011|date=December 23, 2004|publisher=[[CTV News]]}} Näslund missed three games as a result of the hit. In a rematch, Bertuzzi began following Moore around the ice, attempting to provoke him into another fight. With Moore ignoring him, Bertuzzi grabbed Moore's jersey from behind and punched him in the back of the head, with Moore's face hitting the ice as they both fell down. Bertuzzi, as well as several other players from both teams, landed atop Moore as he fell to the ice.{{Cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/news/story?id=1756628|title=Suspension amounts to minimum 17 games|accessdate=February 27, 2007|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=March 12, 2004}} Bertuzzi was assessed a [[penalty (ice hockey)#Match penalty|match penalty]] and ejected from the game. Per league rules, he was also suspended indefinitely pending a ruling from league commissioner [[Gary Bettman]]. After lying on the ice for approximately 10 minutes, Moore was removed from the playing surface on a stretcher.{{cite news|title=A blow by blow account |url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/indepth/bertuzzi/timeline/ |accessdate=March 4, 2011 |date=March 11, 2004 |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628234837/http://www.cbc.ca/sports/indepth/bertuzzi/timeline/ |archivedate=June 28, 2011 }} He was treated for three fractured [[vertebrae]] in his neck, a grade three concussion, vertebral ligament damage, stretching of the [[brachial plexus]] nerves, and facial lacerations. He was also suffering from [[amnesia]].{{cite news|title=Avalanche release update on Moore's condition|url=http://msn.foxsports.com/nhl/story/Avalanche-release-update-on-Moore%27s-condition|accessdate=August 29, 2012|date=March 22, 2004|publisher=[[Fox Sports]]}} Bertuzzi apologized to Moore and his family, as well as to Burke, Canucks owner [[John McCaw, Jr.]], the Canucks organization, his teammates, and the fans in a press conference two days later.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/story/2004/03/10/bertuzzi040310.html|title=Bertuzzi apologizes to Moore|date=March 10, 2004|accessdate=March 3, 2011|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]}} On March 11, 2004, the league ruled he would remain suspended for at least the remainder of the Canucks' season, which ultimately cost him the final 13 games of the regular season plus seven playoff games. The Canucks were additionally fined $250,000. While the following NHL season was suspended due to the [[2004–05 NHL lockout|2004–05 lockout]], Bertuzzi intended to play in Europe, but the [[International Ice Hockey Federation]] (IIHF) extended his NHL suspension to cover their jurisdiction.{{cite news|title=IIHF rules Bertuzzi can't play in Europe|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/hockey/2002123533_nhl18.html|accessdate=February 14, 2011|date=December 18, 2004|work=[[The Seattle Times]]|publisher=Frank A. Blethen|location=Seattle}} Bertuzzi remained professionally inactive during the 2004–05 season. The IIHF's sanction also kept him from representing Canada in the [[2004 Men's World Ice Hockey Championships|2004]] and [[2005 Men's World Ice Hockey Championships|2005 World Championships]], as well as the [[2004 World Cup of Hockey|2004 World Cup]].{{cite news|title=A star player goes offside |url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/indepth/bertuzzi/ |accessdate=March 4, 2011 |date=February 15, 2005 |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100328115858/http://www.cbc.ca/sports/indepth/bertuzzi/ |archivedate=March 28, 2010 }} Bettman scheduled a reinstatement hearing for Bertuzzi on April 26, 2005. The hearing was attended separately by Bertuzzi and Moore. Prior to the [[2005–06 NHL season|2005–06 season]], Bettman announced Bertuzzi's reinstatement on August 8, citing that "Mr. Bertuzzi had paid a very significant price for his conduct," adding that he felt Bertuzzi was "genuinely remorseful and apologetic."{{Cite web|url=http://www.nhl.com/news/2005/08/232342.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719003929/http://www.nhl.com/news/2005/08/232342.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=July 19, 2008|title=NHL reinstates Vancouver's Todd Bertuzzi|accessdate=February 27, 2007|publisher=[[National Hockey League]]|date=August 8, 2005 }} Bertuzzi's 17-month suspension caused him to miss a total of 20 games—the fourth-longest suspension in NHL history at the time.{{Cite web|url=http://proicehockey.about.com/cs/history/a/nhl_suspensions.htm|title=The Longest NHL Suspensions|accessdate=November 21, 2007|author=Jamie Fitzpatrick|publisher=[[New York Times Company]]}} The suspension accounted for $501,926.39 in forfeited salary, as well as an approximate $350,000 in lost endorsements.{{cite news|title=NHL reinstates Bertuzzi after long suspension|url=http://swo.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20050809/bertuzzi_return050808?hub=TorontoNewHome|accessdate=March 4, 2011|date=August 8, 2005|publisher=[[CTV News]]}} On the day of his reinstatement, Team Canada's executive director, [[Wayne Gretzky]], offered him a spot on the national team's summer orientation camp in preparation for the [[Ice hockey at the 2006 Winter Olympics|2006 Winter Olympics]].{{Cite news|title=Bertuzzi breaks silence following suspension|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/hockey/nhl/canucks/2005-08-16-bertuzzi-returns_x.htm|accessdate=March 4, 2011|date=August 16, 2005|work=[[USA Today]]|publisher=Gannett Company|location=McLean, Virginia}} ===Legal actions=== After a four-month investigation, the criminal justice branch of the [[Attorney General of British Columbia]] announced formal charges of [[assault causing bodily harm]] against Bertuzzi on June 24, 2004.{{cite news|title=Bertuzzi charged with assault|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/story/2004/06/24/bertuzzi040624.html|accessdate=March 3, 2011|date=June 24, 2004|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]}} With the charge, Bertuzzi faced up to one-and-a-half years in prison.{{cite news|title=Moore files another lawsuit against Bertuzzi|url=http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/11373324/|accessdate=February 28, 2011|date=February 15, 2006|publisher=[[NBC Sports]]}} Bertuzzi pleaded guilty to the assault charge on December 22 after arranging a [[plea bargain]] with prosecutors. He was given a [[conditional discharge]] requiring 80 hours of [[community service]] and one year's [[probation]] that additionally prohibited him from playing in any hockey game Moore was competing in. Under [[Canadian law]], Bertuzzi's successful completion of his probationary period precluded him from a [[criminal record]].{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2004/12/22/bertuzzi_guilty041222.html|title=Bertuzzi receives conditional discharge, probation|accessdate=February 27, 2007|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]| date=December 24, 2004}} Moore expressed disappointment regarding Bertuzzi's discharge and was upset that he was unable to attend the court date, having to issue a written victim statement instead. Moore's lawyer, Tim Danson, was given one day's notice of the court date following Bertuzzi's plea bargain, which he said was insufficient time for Moore to travel to Vancouver.{{cite news|title=Moore still waiting for Bertuzzi's apology|url=http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/6751136/|accessdate=March 3, 2011|date=December 24, 2004|publisher=[[NBC Sports]]}} On February 17, 2005, Moore filed a [[lawsuit]] in a Colorado court against Bertuzzi, numerous individuals within the Canucks organization, including Brad May (Bertuzzi's teammate at the time who was quoted as saying that there would "definitely be a price on Moore's head" after Moore's hit on Näslund), Brian Burke, Marc Crawford, as well as the Canucks organization as a whole and the [[Orca Bay Sports and Entertainment]] company that owned the team. The lawsuit was thrown out in October 2005, as the Colorado judge ruled the case was better suited for Canadian courts, as Moore and all the defendants were Canadian citizens. Planning to appeal the decision,{{Cite web|url=https://www.tsn.ca/nhl/news_story/?ID=142413&hubname=nhl|title=Moore plans to file appeal in civil case|accessdate=November 21, 2007 |publisher=[[The Sports Network]]|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070929173940/http://www.tsn.ca/nhl/news_story/?ID=142413&hubname=nhl |archivedate = September 29, 2007}} Danson stated publicly the following month that Moore had begun skating and doing regular workouts, but continued to suffer [[post-concussion syndrome|concussion-related symptoms]]. On February 16, 2006, Moore filed another lawsuit in the [[Ontario Superior Court]] against Bertuzzi, the Canucks, and Orca Bay, seeking [[Canadian dollar|CAD$]]15 million in pecuniary damages for loss of income, CAD$1 million for aggravated damages, and CAD$2 million for punitive damages. Moore's parents, who were watching their son on television when the attack happened, also sued, seeking CAD$1.5 million for "negligent infliction of [[nervous shock]] and mental distress".{{Cite news|title=Acrimonious lawsuit drags on and on|url=http://www.canada.com/theprovince/news/sports/story.html?id=b0fc60f1-8ff0-4a05-b3b3-605c21fc2453|accessdate=February 28, 2011|date=November 27, 2007|work=[[The Province]]|publisher=Postmedia Network|location=Vancouver|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628221556/http://www.canada.com/theprovince/news/sports/story.html?id=b0fc60f1-8ff0-4a05-b3b3-605c21fc2453|archivedate=June 28, 2011|df=mdy-all}} In December 2006, Bettman and top lieutenant [[Bill Daly]] facilitated a meeting between Moore's representatives and the defendants in hopes of agreeing on an out-of-court settlement.{{cite news|title=No hype in latest praise of Crosby|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nhl/story/9873254|publisher=[[CBS Sports]]|date=December 16, 2006|accessdate=February 28, 2011}} An out-of-court settlement was reached in Moore's lawsuit in October 2014. Terms of the settlement are confidential.{{cite web |url=http://www.freep.com/article/20140819/SPORTS05/308190100/todd-bertuzzi-steve-moore-settlement | title=Todd Bertuzzi settles lawsuit with Steve Moore over on-ice hit | publisher=''[[Detroit Free Press]]'' | date=August 19, 2014 | accessdate=August 19, 2014}} ==Personal life== Bertuzzi was born and raised in [[Sudbury, Ontario]]. His father, Albert Bertuzzi, is an [[Italian-Canadian]] who worked in the window-washing business. When Bertuzzi was a teenager, Albert survived a near-fatal car accident in which he was thrown from the vehicle through the windshield. His father has stated that he was proud of his own local reputation as a "dirty player" and referred to it as a "Bertuzzi trait".{{cite news|title=Force of nature|url=http://espn.go.com/magazine/vol5no21bertuzzi.html|accessdate=February 14, 2011|date=September 30, 2002|work=[[ESPN Magazine]]|publisher=[[ESPN Inc.]]|location=Bristol, Connecticut}} He has said that Bertuzzi takes after him in regards to his toughness and aggression. Bertuzzi's great-uncle, Larry Bertuzzi, is a [[Toronto]]-based lawyer who has done arbitration work for the NHL, including on the [[Eric Lindros trade]].{{cite news|title=Islanders Pick Name With a Ring to It|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/06/27/sports/hockey-islanders-pick-name-with-a-ring-to-it.html?pagewanted=1|accessdate=June 17, 2010|date=June 27, 1993|work=[[The New York Times]]|location=New York}} Growing up, Bertuzzi played [[minor ice hockey|minor hockey]] with the Nickel Centre and Sudbury Minor Hockey programs. In 1990–91, Bertuzzi played as an underaged player in the major midget ranks with the Sudbury Capitals AAA team. Physically built as a power forward throughout his youth, he stood 6 feet and 2 inches (1.88 metres) and weighed 195 pounds (88.5 kilograms) by age 15.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} Bertuzzi and his wife, Julie, were married in July 1996.{{cite web|title=1998 IIHF World Championship - Players|url=http://hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/4730/la_id/1.htm|accessdate=February 28, 2011|publisher=[[Hockey Canada]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706182717/http://hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/4730/la_id/1.htm|archivedate=July 6, 2011|df=mdy-all}} They have two children born one-and-a-half years apart in [[Vancouver]], a son named Tag and a daughter named Jaden.{{cite news | url = http://www.canada.com/national/features/raiseareader/story.html?id=3728e46c-bd3b-4261-a021-d322355cabed | title = Bertuzzis know kids' path to success made richer by reading | last = Woodend | first = Dorothy | work = The Vancouver Sun | publisher = Postmedia Network | location = Vancouver | date = October 3, 2002 | accessdate = April 15, 2008 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081206174543/http://www.canada.com/national/features/raiseareader/story.html?id=3728e46c-bd3b-4261-a021-d322355cabed | archivedate = December 6, 2008 | df = mdy-all }} His son, Tag Bertuzzi, was drafted into the OHL by the [[Guelph Storm]], 2nd overall in 2017.http://ontariohockeyleague.com/draft Bertuzzi is a recreational golfer and has credited the sport with allowing him to relax more as a hockey player. During his 10-game suspension from the NHL in October and November 2001, he played golf to focus his energy. Afterwards, he made it a custom to go to the driving range before every game. January 3 – February 4, 2003) (tied with [[Petr Nedvěd|Petr Nedved]]; November 19 – December 27, 1992) *Vancouver Canucks team record; most powerplay goals, single season—25 in [[2002–03 NHL season|2002–03]] (tied with [[Pavel Bure]]) ==Transactions== * June 26, 1993: Drafted 23rd overall by the [[New York Islanders]] * July 6, 1995: Signed to a four-year, $4.6 million contract with the New York Islanders * February 6, 1998: Traded to the [[Vancouver Canucks]] from the New York Islanders with [[Bryan McCabe]] and a 3rd round choice in [[1998 NHL Entry Draft|1998]] ([[Jarkko Ruutu]]) for [[Trevor Linden]] * September 1999: Re-signed to a two-year contract with the Vancouver Canucks * October 27, 2003: Signed a four-year, $27.9 million contract extension with the Vancouver Canucks * March 11, 2004: Suspended indefinitely by the [[National Hockey League|NHL]] for deliberate injury to [[Steve Moore (ice hockey)|Steve Moore]] in a game versus the [[Colorado Avalanche]] * August 8, 2005: Officially reinstated by the NHL * June 23, 2006: Traded to the [[Florida Panthers]] by the Vancouver Canucks with [[Bryan Allen (ice hockey)|Bryan Allen]] and [[Alex Auld]] for [[Roberto Luongo]], [[Lukáš Krajíček|Lukas Krajicek]] and a sixth-round draft choice in [[2006 NHL Entry Draft|2006]] ([[Sergei Shirokov]]) * February 27, 2007: Traded to the [[Detroit Red Wings]] by the Florida Panthers for prospect [[Shawn Matthias]] and conditional draft picks * July 2, 2007: Signed a two-year, $8 million contract as an [[unrestricted free agent]] with the [[Anaheim Ducks]] * June 28, 2008: Placed on [[waivers (NHL)|waivers]] by the Anaheim Ducks; Wimbush|publisher=Wipf and Stock Publishers|year=2012|isbn= 9781610979641}} is a traditional name of the Yoruba ethnic group for females which factors into [[Yoruba mythology]], meaning "Mother has returned".{{cite web|url=http://www.thenamemeaning.com/yetunde/|title=Girl names, Baby names: Yetunde|website=The Name Meaning|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com.ng/books?id=Y21XOYRQUgQC&pg=PA40&dq=|title=Mythologies|publisher=PediaPress|page=40}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com.ng/books?id=bOdSMvlA7zsC&pg=PA134&lpg=PA134&dq=|page=134|title=Ethnic and Cultural Diversity in Nigeria|author1=Marcellina Ulunma Okehie-Offoha|author2=Matthew N. O. Sadiku|publisher=Africa World Press|year=1996|ISBN=978-0-865-4328-33}} Notable people with the name include: * [[Sasha P|Anthonia Yetunde Alabi]], Nigerian musician and businesswoman. * [[Yetunde Onanuga]], Nigerian politician * [[Yetunde Price]], the elder half-sister of tennis players Venus Williams and Serena Williams. * [[Andi Osho|Yewande Osho]], British comedian and actress. * [[Yewande Adekoya]], Nigerian actress. * [[Yewande Akinola]], Nigerian engineer Notable people with the alternative name form include: * [[Iyabo Obasanjo-Bello]], daughter of Nigerian former president. * [[Iyabo Anisulowo]], Nigerian politician * [[Iyabo Ojo]], Nigerian actress. * [[Funke Osibodu|Olufunke Iyabo Osibodu]], Nigerian banker * [[Lola Wallinkoski|Iyabode Ololade Remilekun Wallinkoski]], Finnish model. * [[Comfort Momoh|Comfort Iyabo Momoh]] British-Nigerian nurse/midwife. ==See also== *[[Babatunde]] *[[Tunde]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Yoruba given names]] [[Category:African feminine given names]] [[Category:Reincarnation]] {{name-stub}}
